Entry.1:
Reveille 5 am. Bfast 6.30, Parade 7.15. Left Camp 9 am. Sydney 10.30 marched to Wharf via Park St. Wharf 11.30. On deck 12.10 left 12.20. Anchored between Cremorne & Garden Island Good dinner then, and had afternoon to look over boat, weighed anchor 4.45 and passed out Heads 5 pm. Tea immediately after & then issue of bedding. Lovely day & night sorting things together and retired 9 p.m.

May 13

Up 5.45 am. Breakfast 7.15 nothing to do. Muster Parade 11 am. lecture of tidyness of ship etc & orderlies duties dinner noon 3 course Parade 2 Pm. Marking and stowing Kits & Packs in respective alloted bins. Tea 5pm. Passed 2 large cargo ships Weather slight rain all morning, cleared pm. but clouded later, very cool on deck. Writing afternoon & evening. Issued with canvas shoes. Men alloted to respective sections Time dragged rather. but ship etc. very satisfactory. Writing all evening Bed 8.30 pm

May 14 W.N.W. 330 M.

Reveille 6 a.m., had about ½ hours physical drill on Boat deck. Breakfast 8 a.m., Porridge, Fish fried, Bread and tea. Parade 9.30 am Rifle ex. & Firing position standing load. In charge of 12 men, draw meet & potatoes for ship. 20 sheep, 16 of beef. 6 bales sausages. 12 sacks of potatoes Dinner usual time, good. Afternoon given for mending clothes, etc; 5 pm. tea. same as 13th. music & dancing, singing and other high spirited amusement followed, played table games till 9 then to bed. Sea steady swell, weather 

May 15th

Woke up to find it very dark and rainy & windy sea about same as 14th. Running on deck & other physical drill till breakfast. Sausages & Porridge etc. passed sailingship on starboard side about mile off same time going opposite direction.

9 a.m. Parade Musketry between showers. sea rising. Dinner stewed rabit & vegetables. To wet & rough for drill afternoon. wind & sea high by tea.-time. all temporary structure on fore deck lashed down for weather. music after tea. Bed 7.30 pm.
Entry.2:
Miles

Up 6 am as usual to find place awash. Washing house smashed in by seas, speed reduced to nearly a standstill, sea still high, high wind on port bow & cold with rain on & off. spray often over bow. No parades. 
Sausages
 Chops etc; breakfast, no duty all day reading most of morning C.S. & Magazine. Dinner roast meet, vegetables currant pudding, Beeftea. Showery all day, very little sun at all. Many off their food. Reading, Writing & sleeping till teatime. Singing & reading till 8 pm then bed. Showery all day & cold wind sea.

May 17th

Physical drill at 9 
p
 am. Medical inspection at 10. and lecture on boat drill Boat drill at 2 Pm. given positions only in case of alarm. games from 3 till 4 pm. After tea singing and writing. Bed 8.30 pm. Weather still showery, wind & sea steadier but still cold, full speed again, 
W.S.W.
 direction WNW 195 Miles.

May 18th

Physical drill before breakfast; after drill order with rifles, musketry, triger pressing, aiming all positions. Afternoon given for mending clothes. I spent it reading, writing and sleeping. After tea spent time on deck till 7.30 then writing. Letters Kitty & Eva, Cards to. Mother, & Sanders, letter to solicitors. Weather much better sun all morning cloudy afternoon, evening clear & mild. Speed full, Course W.N.W. 290 Miles.

May 19th

Physical drill before breakfast. 9-30 Drill order with rifles, Bayonet fighting, lecture on Correspondence, lecture on aiming & parts of rifle, saw whale blowing about 9 a.m., came in sight of land on starboard side, low scattered hills first then higher chain later, ran parallel with them all day. Full marching order & inspection after dinner, later lecture on Landscape targets with map. After tea, haircut & writing & reading, sentinel. Concert after deck. Weather beautiful, sun & sea, fair wind W.N.W. direction, 313 M.

May 20th

Up 5-30 a.m. Past Cape Leeuin 11 p.m., 19/5/15, last of Australian coast. Batt. Ord. Cpl. for day. Beautiful calm weather & sea. Bright sun all day, lovely sunset & evening. Course N.N.W., 316 miles, 24 hrs. to noon today, position just below Freemantle. Had large double tooth taken, sitting on jam case during action, lovely ? reading during evening.

Covering ship with awning for Tropical climate.

May 21st

Physical drill, breakfast. 4 hrs. Boat positions & roll call respective boats. Musketry standing .trigger pressing till 11, 11-12. muscle ex. & Fire disciplins.

Afternoon given make & mend, washing, etc; Washed shirt & 2 of socks sports held on boat deck, Musketry reading after tea. Signaling. Beautiful weather beginning to feel the heat even from sun rise. Mileage 333. Course N.N.W.

May 22nd N.N.W., M. 318

Physical Drill, after Bkfast. Rifle ex. 10 a.m., airing blankets, hoisted on lines to masts. Lecture on Military spirit, British ambition of manliness in soldiering 11.40. Last 20" given to section commanders, instruction in musketry, standing load & firing. 10-15 a.m. Gun practice, testing after guns. After dinner collecting blankets, had to give lecture myself to platoon on Saluting, from 3-15 Landscape targets. 4-10 p.m. Fire alarm & boat positions. Lovely day, rather cloudy & warm even.

Jan. 12th Wednesday

Jan. 9th Sunday

Dissembarked Alexandria at 8-15 a.m. Marched down line to Timber works where we waited train till 12-40 p.m. Y.M.C.A. on Stn. & plenty of fruit & native dealers about. Nile much flooded. Reached Zagazig 6 p.m. and Tel el Kebir about 8-15 p.m., our camp site some ¼ hour away where we rec’d tea all roung & then pitched tents getting to bed 10 p.m.

Monday, Jan. 10th

Pitched tents properly in Regimental order

May 23rd N.N.W. M.314

Up usual time 6-30. 7-30 physical drill. Dress for Church Parade. Dress with Cap & shoes. Parade at 9-5 a.m., Service about 9-30 on Port side Boat Deck, Band in attendance. Good service. After mending till dinner. Afternoon C & S reading and resting about deck. After tea quiet talk with Goode on N.Z. and present occupation, spent remainder of evening at Service, good singing, lecture on Drinking & habits. Weather morning changeable, fair after dinner.

early & later rec’d our accumulated mails, 35 letters &, 6 parcels, 1 Journal & 1 Paper. After dinner had good 

bath & change. Had long walk round Camp roads & turned in about 9 p.m.

Jan. 11th Tues.

Began full routine, Physical D. 7 to 7-30 a.m., Bkfst

. 8 a.m., Morning P. 9-30 to 11-30, Dinner 12-00. Afternoon Parade 1-30-4.30, tea 5 p.m, Lights out 10 p.m. Reveille 6-15 a.m. Wounded return letter from K.

Jan. 12th

Usual camp routine, another wounded return 

May 24 N.N.W. M.320

Physical drill as usual. 9-30 Lecture on sleeping on deck and alteration in future parade hours during tropical weather which from now are:- 6-30-7-15, Physical, 9-30-11 a.m., 2-30-4 p.m. No one allowed to stay below deck between meals except special cases. Sections lecturing individually on parts of rifle; aiming; muscle exercises. Afternoon lecture on Fire discipline etc. & Landscape targets. Several sharp showers till 10 a.m., later very nice, beautiful afternoon. Very warm below deck still. 

from K. & 2 Regtd. letters (1 from home & Pkt. pair socks etc. from Mrs. B.)

Jan. 13 Thurs.

B. Coy .Duty day. Self Batt .

Jan. 14 Friday

17th Batt. for Bgde. duty. Stacking horse fodder all day at 2nd Div. A.S.C.

Jan. 15 Sat.

Rehearsing parade for Divisional inspection in morning & General’s Inspection afternoon, 1st & 2nd Division.

Jan. 16 Sun.

Rifle inspection 7-30 a.m. Church parade 10 a.m. Sent Cable to Sanders after dinner also 13 letters 

May 25th N.N.W. M.322

Coy for Duty myself Cpl. of Guard over stern Gun 9-30 – 24 hrs. 4 men 2 hrs. on six off, no physical drill for Guards. Ship’s officers rifle shooting floating boxes etc., range by sextant 5 to 1400 good shots. 2-30 p.m. dropped Life belt practice man over. Lowered boat, ship turned right round & reached belt same time as boat. Gun practice 6 a piece at 6 ft. sq. target drifting astern, engines stopped, good aiming, all over 4 p.m. & reviewed course. Card writing on after deck from sunset, study after from 7-30. Weather perfect nearly. 

written at Lemnos, ‘Simla’, Alexandria & Tel-el-Kebir up to date. Weekend Cable fee 41 Millemes per word to Australia and 10 Millemes for England. Dinner today as follows:- 1st Salmon, Tomatoes & Sauce, 2nd Xmas pudding & Tinned Apricots with Cond. Milk, 3rd Sweets & Chocolates, 4th Tea.

Tea 5 p.m.

1st Curry & rice,
Entry.5: Rec’d Negatives from Photographer all very fair.
Entry.6:
N.N.W. M.300

1-30 a.m. awakened from Guard sleep on open deck aft, big rain for about ½ hour, swung hamock later. Up 5 a.m. call, relief, shave, etc. 10 a.m. Bath & washing towel Hdkf. cleaning wht. shoes, then rested till dinner, study hour & ½ after. Lecture from 2-30/4 p.m. on Military vocabulary. Study after tea till sunset which was one of the best seen. just lovely. all colours & order reflected as glass like sea. Fish very interesting, flying & jumping. Heavy showers early .
Entry.7: Struck tents afternoon, had to sleep out all night that that transports may be loaded, were to leave 2-30 a.m. but postponed till 9-30 a.m.
Entry.8: entrained 9-30 a.m. steamed out nearer 10-30 in open trucks reaching Ismalia 11-30; later marched through same along canal, Scenery just charming with its Canal & tropical growth. Had midday meal at flood gates opening into Suez Canal & after another hour’s tramp reached Punts where we all put hands
Entry.9:
N.N.W. M.325

Coy Orderly Cpl. for day parading sick 9 a.m. & 5-30 p.m. about the only duties realy required. Sighted ship’s smoke ahead at 7a.m. over took her at 11a.m. ‘Sontay’ troopship french aboard. All our men ordered on deck, returned theirs & our Nationals also 3 cheers, a very thrilling few minutes, she was very crowded & slow, soon left behind. Had to put man through 10" Pack drill 6 p.m. listening to band & studying. bath & bed 

to loading & unloading baggage etc. across Suez, when all complete marched on to Camp ‘Fairy Post’ about mile beyond Canal where we spent night on the open sands; very cold & slight showers.

25th Tuesday

Put tents up & had drill all day; several heavy rain storms; slept in tents.
Entry.10: Struck tents about 7 a.m. and with full pack etc. set off for
Entry.11: Line of Defence some 8 miles east of Canal. On journey many dropped out so had to remain with them & followed later as able on Donkeys commandeered
Entry.12:
N.N.W. M.308

Physical drill to 7-15, N.C.O. Lecture till 7-40, 9-30-10 a.m. Full Marching orders, Saluting, Musketry & Lecture from O.C. 11-15 Retire. Afternoon washing Dungaree pants & Flannel & Hakf. Signaling & reading. Studying & listening to band after tea. Bath.

May 29th

Usual drill. Mainly lectures on Duties of Sec. Commanders. Long Bible Reading evening, Band & Bed. 

en route. Took photo of our ‘Straglers Transport’ and when within about 2 miles of destination had to leave donkeys and put our gear on Transport Camels. Later on various units separating had to unload & waited for return of empty camels which I hired for use of our party. While waiting in open sands caught in very heavy storm getting well nigh soaked, reached camp site about 3pm. & found tents up so sorted ourselves out & parted. Night’s sleep much appreciated.

Fine Anniversary Day.

½ mile Nth. of Hill 353. 

May 30

Sighted land early. Up at 5am. watching shore, stood by outside barrier till Pilot came aboard, entered harbour at about 6.30am. Church parade same time. Coal lighters 10 or 12 & 2 water ditto came alongside about 7am. swarmed with coloured folk or all colours to barter etc. I was Cpl. of Gun Guard aft. First shore party left 11-15am., 2nd noon, 3rd 1-30pm., 4th 4pm. 3rd marched v. Queen St., Bridge St., Shorts Rd. through Barracks Park, Queen St. to wharf 

27th Thursday 

Reported with 6 men to 5th Engineers for duty. Marking out Fire Positions (Trenches). Coy moved on Nth. to Canberra Post 
fro
 about 2 miles off and pitched tents. Much rain in showers. No. 8 on outpost duty from 6pm. till 6am. following day. Wet & bitterly cold & tired.

28th Friday

Continued with Engineering officer on Canberra Redoubt during afternoon. Morn. at rest.
Entry.13:
Measuring & shallow trenching redoubt trenches ready for workmen, finished about 4.30pm. 

30th Continued 217M.

We 3rd party re-embarked at 5-30pm., all on ship at 7pm., sailed out of Barrier at 9-30, slept on after deck on duty. Weather cloudy but fine, extremely hot on march. Lights out after 10pm.
Entry.14:
N.N.W. M.303

Relieved from Guard at 9-30. Muster Parade called same time, remained on deck but not on duty till 11am. Retire. Sighted high mountains on starboard at 8am. 9-30 natives in Cat - ? in all directions about 5 miles off shore, left them behind after noon, land in sight all day. Lecture Sec. Cmdrs. Good Breeze cool deck, hot below. 	,

Sunday 30th

Final alterations to Canberra Redoubt thence to Lithgow Post. Coy shifted camp N.W. some 300 yds. into deep hollow nearer Canal.

Monday 31st

Siting different position for Lithgow Redoubt all day. Very cold wind.

February commenced in check covered Book.

Diary
Entry.16:
N.N.W. M.301

Drill as usual. Afternoon writing, slept over tea time, awoke at ‘Sunset’. Study, Band, Bath, Bed 8-30. Weather fine & clear & hot. Position noon N. of Laccadive Island. Payday. £1 received.
Entry.17:
West. M.314

Usual drill. Physical, Musketry, Morning C.S. Reading midday. Afternoon visual T. by section Cmrs. & Burial Service at 3-30 to 4-15pm. Manning C. Coy. Writing & Study & Reading B.
Entry.18:
West. 323M.

Physical Drill. Parade Bt. Deck at 8am. Celebration.

June 3rd continued

Mending & letter writing. Reading novels & B. L & S Officers revolver practice afternoon, reading night.
Entry.19:
323M. West

B. Coy on Duty in charge of own section for Phy. D. till 7am. then on with Canteen Fatigue, very hot & on the go all day till 8-30, good music & singing aft.
Entry.20:
West. M.305

Usual drill all day. Outpost in addition. At reveille we were running along the Socotra Island, very rough & high mountains also passed 2 ships, one 7-30am. other .
Entry.21:
W. 318M.

Physical Drill. Church Parade 9-30. Boat drill 10-30am. Reading & lying about till 4pm. Card writing & letter diary & Church service from 4 till 8-45. The day was terribly hot. Saw much land, passed several ships.
Entry.22:
N.W. 314M.

Passed Aden during night. Passed Is. of Perim, Fortified Island about 6.30am. land in sight most of day. Volcanic Is. & … Is. midday. On Fatigues. very hot working, lovely breeze after.
Entry.23:
N.N.W. 314M.

Burial Service 7am. Drill as usual mainly lecture by Commander. Hot morning, cooler afternoon, stiff breeze night. Mending afternoon to reading & sleep, no land in sight.
Entry.24:
N.N.W. 317M.

Usual daily routine, land very indistinct outline. Hot am., much cooler pm., considerably cooler all day. Reading morning till 9am., also evening. Ship getting her windlasses set for unloading fore & aft.
Entry.25:
N.N.W. 320M.

Orderly Cpl. Company, reading novels most day, passed many ships several transports & Hospital Ship towards sunset. Running up kind of narrowing channel from midday. Rec’d Identification disk & Pay Book to make out Will Form. Beautiful weather cool, good breeze.
Entry.26:
Reached Port Suez about 3 a.m. Usual Morning Parades. Afternoon given to returning blkts. & getting Baggage ready for landing. Awnings 

11th

concert proposed & partly kept up. All hands took up Kitchen utensils as band instruments in order to get blankets, but failed.

June 12th

Up 5 a.m. Orderly Cpl., time dragged terribly. 1st party left ship about 10-30, 2nd 1-40 p.m.,
Entry.27:
about 5 p.m. 1-40 p.m. reached Heliopolis, at 8-30 gave kits to baggage waggons & marched to camp. Waited about there for quarters but finally turned in to rough it in Eating sheds, sleeping in clothing. Up 6 a.m., paraded for our kits 7 a.m. Lecture at 11 a.m. by Colonel not 25 of. present .

Doubt though not entered daily.

13th

Issued with Blkts. & Sheet 7 p.m. Finished Kittie’s letters off & posted at G.P.O. 8 p.m. Bought Camera midday near Y.M.C.A. Dust & heat awfull. 

Coy. for duty fatigues taken but remainder doing nothing, lounging in shade till 9 a.m. Bkft. 9-15.
Entry.28:
on opp. Page.

Entrained 1-40 p.m. Suez, detrained 8-30 Heliopolis, arrived Camp about 10 p.m., retired about 10-30 to 11 p.m. in Mess Sheds as we were where we lived for several days. Put tents up on Thursday & occupied them same night, 24 men to each. Camera
Entry.31: Church Parade 6-15 a.m. got Pass & left for Cairo 10-30 with 4 others. Spoke to 1st woman since
Entry.32: at Resturant. Visited Pyramids after dinner, got back Cairo 6-30 p.m., after tea had a look round city getting to camp 10 p.m.
Entry.33: Coy. on Duty. Cpl. & 6 men to Guard Nurses Home. Ibraheim Palace. Mounted 10 a.m. Visited Heliopolis shopping 5 p.m. to 6.
Entry.34: Took films to be developed & printed 9-30. Visited by Capt. Kirke, all well.
Entry.35: Tried all town for Frame, got one & did some printing late evening, all well. Writing night.
Entry.36: Printing negatives, etc., took several photos. Went for watch after tea. Writing afternoon. Washing Hdkfs.
Entry.37: Photography most of day, out for while in evening back about 9 p.m.
Entry.38: Letter writing & reading, out 2 hrs. after dinner.
Entry.39:
Relieved 10-30 a.m., marched back leaving kits for wagon following.

Diary of Camp Work.
Entry.40: Arrived home from all night manoeuvre about
Entry.41: Tower. Rested all day, letter writing evening.
Entry.45: Reveille 4 a.m. Marched through to Citadel, stayed all day, left 5 p.m., arriving Heliopolis 8-45 p.m.
Entry.47: Packing all day. Left Camp (Heliopolis) 7 p.m. Marched to Zeitoun thence by train to Alexandria, detrained
Entry.48: and Embarked on ‘Alaunia’ (Cunard Line, Liverpool) at 3 a.m., Monday. Lay at wharf loading till 5-30 p.m., tea followed same & Full dress parade on B Deck 6-30 p.m. Took up sleeping positions on same deck 8 p.m. as safeguard against attack etc. opposite our life boats.
Entry.49: Reveille 5-30 a.m. Bkfst. at 7-30 a.m., Parade mixed uses 9-30 also inoculated against Cholera. 25 Best rifle shots called from each Platoon as Special Guard against Submarine attack. Posted 1st sentries 11-30 a.m., ¼ hr. watches.
Entry.50:
Passed British war craft, cruiser & submarine about 6-30 a.m. Steadied engines 2-30 p.m., anchored at Lemnos about 3 p.m. The ships in port simply amazing. War crafts of all descriptions as well as Red Cross & Transports. Harbour well mined all over especially across channel. Drew anchor & steamed further up harbour in among the numerous ships & again dropped anchor 
about
 for night about 6 p.m. Several photos taken. Many of the boys arrested for diving overboard. Submarine Guard dismissed at 2-30 p.m.
Entry.51: Lay in Lemnos all day, sailed at 4-45 p.m. in two boat loads of 1000 each. Reached coast for dissembarking 12-30 & started landing about 3-30 a.m. in pontoons of about 60 men. Only ashore about 2 hours when enemy guns got range of our late ship which soon put her to sea. Seeing the nature of the land, the earlier troops who have gained it deserve utmost credit, it seems almost impossible to take.
Entry.52: Lay in 1st position till 7-30 p.m. then moved off to left
Entry.53: about 2 miles. Slept in gulley all night, 3 wounded by stray Bullets. Beach shelled where our boys were bathing & getting water. Moved off further and took up Bivouack just rear of our trenches, midday (1-30) between heavy Gun duel all afternoon. Navy & land batteries gainst Turks shells flying overhead all day. Two Platoons of C Coy moved over to assist in trenches, remainder slept in readiness.
Entry.54: Violent infantry attack commenced about 3.30 a.m. lasting about 2 hours. Good issue of rations given. Battery duel continues aided still by Navy.
Entry.55:
All day in same Gulley reading & sleeping. Water carrying 9 to 10 p.m.

from Beach Pump & had a wash.
Entry.56: 9-30 Changed Base to relieve 14 Batt., dug ourselves in & all O.K. 1 p.m. No duty again all day. 1 Platoon in trenches 48 hrs. from 6 p.m.
Entry.57: Stand to Arms 4 a.m. from now on. Had look into our own trenches. Carried Despatch to H.Qrs. at No. 2 Outpost C & D Coys front.
Entry.58: No work all day. Swim at Beach 8 p.m., 1st bath since landing. Mails closed 1 p.m.
Entry.59:
24 hrs. rations & 200 rounds am. Moved off from Quarters 3 p.m. to 15th Quarters, waited here during Gun Bombardment, started 3-45 & rifle fire & inf. attack 5 p.m. lasting

nearly all night. In thick of it, we moved forward in rear of 16th & 17th line about 7 p.m., returning about hour later. Roused 10 p.m. & again moved to the Line where we commenced digging the communication trenches on extreme left near N.Z’rs.; being relieved 5 a.m., returned to our reserve gulley as earlier for rest & safety till further orders. (Midday writing up.)

18th Saturday continued.

Rested all day. 8 p.m. Manned Trenches
Entry.60: Line (Left flank) 24 hrs., withdrawing 9 p.m. Sunday, sleeping close by.
Entry.61: Returned to reserve gullie 5 a.m. to rest till 7 p.m. when we set out for sapping to connect with N.Zrs. Line as before digging all night.
Entry.62:
& Sept.

Continued sapping till 1 p.m. and on returning to Reserve had orders to Stand to to change camp. Returned to own Bivouac Gullie 4 p.m. & left here 7 p.m. with all gear lower down valley where we spent night.
Entry.64:
Red Cross Dressing Stn., moved off 8 p.m. for Popes Post. Halted for night at Shrapnel Gullie about 10 p.m. Sea Bath midday.

2nd Thursday

After many fatigue jobs moved on to Popes Post about 5 p.m. where found rest & comfort in fine large dug-out for night.

3rd Friday

8 Platoon left on Gullie for fatigues while remainder

of Coy took post in Trenches on Summit of hill directly above us. Most of us unfit for duties.

4th Saturday

Still fatigue duties, Water, Wood, Rations, etc.
Entry.65: F. Meat & Swim. Fatigue continues. Letter writing. Had to sleep handy to trenches in case of attacks.
Entry.66: Fatigue, Sleeping at Arms, Alarm midnight for ½ hour.
Entry.70: Reported to Quins Post 10 a.m. as Cpl. of Trench Mortar Section under Sgt. Watson. Demonstration later of day. Quartered in sheds, D Terrace.
Entry.71: Mails distributed 9-30 a.m. then on to Beach, swim & scouring dixies, home 12-30, no duties all day & night, showers. Went up to Mortar with other Cpl. & Sgt. during demonstration 10-30 p.m. when our second bomb failed & through accident exploded hitting 4 of us. One died on way to foot of hill, one other cut up very much, Sgt. & myself merely got splinters slight. Had my knee dressed at Stn. & returned to Shed. Bed 12 p.m.
Entry.72:
Leg much swolen & stiff, redressed. Slept, quiet all day, our section given

new quarters in dug-outs nearer our guns. Very cosy. Only duty all day carrying up Hand Bombs, ½ hour job, no night work.

17th

2nd Reinforcements arrived at Post & begin trench Duty.
Entry.73: Another small mail in early, 2 Parcels from Lindfield. U/load Duties very easy. Very sharp attack with Artillery & Rifle fire from Turks about sunset ½ hour.
Entry.74: Things very quiet on Post all day. Wrote letters.
Entry.76:
Trench Mortar Battery organized, 1 Sgt., 1 Leu. Cpl. over 5 Sections of 5 men,

a Cpl. each.
Entry.79: Demonstration 8 p.m. assisted by artillery about 1 hour in all.
Entry.86:
Bombardment continues South. Very heavy. Dew & fog with clouds hiding sea till midday. Turks siege gun firing on our front from left.

O.
Entry.89:
Very heavy Naval bombardment continued especially from 5 a.m. to 

about 8 a.m. Turks opened very fierce Artillery fire on Posts – Courtneys, Lone Pine, Walkers & Pope’s, particularly from 9 a.m. till about 10 a.m. Our Guns also retaliated and things quietened off again. No rifle fire whatever near our posts during bombardment. Remainder of day very quiet.
Entry.90: Bombardment continues toward south (Naval). Mails in.
Entry.91: Visited Chaplain on Beach & had good bathe & wash, getting back noon, felt the exertion very much, slept all afternoon.
Entry.92:
Quiet during day. Rally at Lone Pine

8-30 – 9-15 with Naval assistance. Rumoured Turks using Gass.
Entry.93: Bread & Meat issued daily this week. Turks Artillery very quiet lately.
Entry.94: Weather threatening all day culminating in severe Gale about 8 p.m. with rain about ½ hour, clearing later.
Entry.95: Weather settled but Beach much effected by gale also water supply pumps damaged.
Entry.96:
Storm worked up again at midday with rain & thunder, cleared later with

bright sun, though much cooler.
Entry.97: New Spring Bomb thrower to hand & tried with much success. Mail in. Weather Bright but cold.
Entry.98: Weather very cold & breezy. Artillery duels during afternoon. Land Batteries only. Big Mail in.
Entry.99:
All very quiet all day. Turks using explosive shells attached to rod for firing during morning against our Post from top of No Man’s Ridge, 2 passed right over our front & Reserves only 1 exploding & without

effect. Shell about 6" long about 6 or 8 lbs. weight.
Entry.100: Turks very quiet indeed. Heavy Naval Bombardment South most of day. Small mail in.
Entry.101: Demonstration given by us 4 a.m. with Artillery & Navy. Poorest yet witnessed, turned in to sleep at 5-30 a.m. Much Artillery & Naval fire later morning, answered weakly by Turks Guns. Very heavy bombmt. South.
Entry.102: Line very quiet. Weather very dull & cold.
Entry.103:
Amusing & friendly exchange of Bully Beef & Jam for

Turkish cigarettes & writing notes. Day & night following quietest yet known.
Entry.104: Another ‘Parapet scene’ & exchange as on 18th, also seen on Courtneys Post till Germans opened fire with artillery & Rocket Bombs of which they placed 17 along their lines with much apparent effect, remainder of day fairly quiet. Evening at Cards.
Entry.105: Business as usual, nothing out of ordinary.
Entry.106: Fair amt. of Artillery fire from both Navy & Batteries. Cards.
Entry.107: Guns very busy all round. Dull all day with light rain from about 3 p.m. Turks using Grenade Mortar on Courtneys Post. We returned fire with our Mortar & they immediately stopped theirs.
Entry.108: Dull & bitterly Cold, later sunshine but wind kept shaded places very chilly. Much heavy firing at Narrows all morning.
Entry.111: Weather very bright & hot. Naval Guns directed toward Beachy Bill with heavy shells during afternoon.
Entry.112: Sky clouded at times but very windy. Combined Naval & Artillery bombardment all along line for about 1 hour midday.
Entry.113: Weather Bright & hot. Fairly quiet along front. Evening commenced early with bomb throwing & kept up very furiously all night. 390 Bombs in all used on whole Post during the night. Small English Mail.
Entry.114: Weather still good. Heavy Gun fire on both flanks also some battery work on & about our front. Turks began fierce Bomb throwing again 4-30 to 5 p.m., remainder of night very quiet.
Entry.115: Weather good & bright. Bread & meat been off since 27th. Gale.
Entry.116: Weather continues good. Bread & Meat issued. Front quiet. Used Japs Mortar 9-30 p.m. to quieten Turks with their Broom Stick Bombs playing on Pope’s. Out for same reason again 1-30 a.m.
Entry.117: Very strong wind during Sunday night to midday with clouds. Beautiful afternoon following. Mail in mainly papers. Front very restless till Garlands were fired over from 8-15 till about 9-30 p.m.
Entry.118: Weather Bright but sharper. Took 4 Photoes with No. 1 Sigs. borrowed Camera, viz., 1. Dugouts of 18 Batt. Gulley, 2. Courtney’s Post from 18 Gulley, 3. Quins Post new Cook houses, 4. My own Dugout. Much Gun fire about 4 to 6 p.m., otherwise front quiet.
Entry.119: Still beautiful weather, front quiet. Beachy busy.
Entry.120:
Weather continues good. Our artillery playing up with Turks during afternoon. Turks blew up mine at No. 6 Post 5-40 p.m., no damage to our firing line but support trenches collapsed with falling earth burying 2 men who died before able to get them out, 3 others were wounded. About 7 to 8 heavy rifle fire commenced near Lone Pine extending along our line by Turks. Garland was kept busy also several rockets fired by us. Appeared to be 3 attacks or rallies on our right, last ending about 10-30 with a few heavy shells

landing on the Turks line in that locality. Big mails in Aust. & Eng.
Entry.121: Weather still bright. Navy guns, lying opposite, firing heavy shells long way inland over top of Lone Pine, could not hear the strike so long was range. Stood to all night with Garland opp. Crater (blown up) No. 6 in shifts of 2 hrs. ea. Front extremely quiet.
Entry.122: Weather continues. Quiet all round during morning except for early Bombardment 4 to 6 a.m.
Entry.123:
Real Sunday weather. Aust. Mail in 4 letters and Parcels 1 ea. from Mabel D.,

Mrs. Sanders, Eileen, very good gifts including sweets, books, underwear, soap & hdkfs. Action quiet all day & night.
Entry.124: Very much colder & duller. Front quiet.
Entry.125: Weather fair. Front quiet. Naval small craft active especially about midday. Cruisers firing heavy broadsides during afternoon onto Gun ridge.
Entry.126: Rain threatening. Turks busy with hand bombs about 10 a.m. on Posts 3 & 6, quietened by Garland & Catapult.
Entry.127:
Much like rain, but

cleared off later. Notified to Report to Coy for future duties. Rec’d Red Cross Comforts (food dainties). Our Engineers mined Turks opp. No. 2 Post 8-30 p.m., followed by a ½ hour’s sharp rifle fire from them.
Entry.128: Cloudy all morning, heavy showers toward midday, afternoon clear sky with bright sun & moonlight night. Camping in Gullie alongside 5th F. Ambulance for week’s rest.
Entry.129: Sky dull & keen air early. Resting & taking things easy. Went down to Y.M.C.A. Canteen & roung beach during afternoon.
Entry.130: Lovely day, felt very tired after Saturday’s walking. Mail in. Reading & resting all day. Rec’d beautiful Cake.
Entry.132: Weather very windy but fine. Quite strong again, out gathering firewood for self during afternoon.
Entry.133: Weather changeable with high wind ending in terrific burst of rain lasting about ¼ hour but flooding everything. Was able to relay my bed after shower & sleep remainder of night from about 8.30.
Entry.134: Weather again simply perfect with slightest breeze drying up things wonderfully. Made some improvements to dug-out against rain. 6-30 p.m. to 10-30 p.m. on Ammunition Fatigue to Beach & back with bomb mule transport. Shelled.
Entry.135: Perfect day. Writing morning. Gass apparatus inspected. Writing evening.
Entry.136: Morning reading & writing, afternoon issuing underwear for Reserve. Ammunition Fatigue 6-30 to 9-30 p.m.
Entry.137:
Eileen Pcl.

Weather very dull and bitterly cold with wind.

Meat & Smokes issue.
Entry.138: Weather continues very dull with slight showers & cold with wind. Meat issued idled the day away reading, tidying, etc. Writing evening.
Entry.139: Weather Dull & Cold still. 9-30 a.m. moved into Trenches, shift 12 to 3 p.m. then changed to 6 to 12 p.m. Tea & Bully for dinner. Stew for tea.
Entry.140:
Still cold & dull, 1 ration boiled bacon breakfast. Tea only dinner. 
Nov. 20th Thursday
 Bully & bisc. for tea. From 6-30 p.m. began evacuation method. Perfect silence all night, no firing by us. Turks working on their parapets most of night.
Entry.141: Turks very plainly visible, heads & shoulders above parapets, later seen to jump over from firing trench to fake bomb trench with rifle & bayonet fixed, attacked posts 3 & 4 about 9 a.m. 1 Turk killed in our trench. Digging been reported hourly below No. 2 post for days, but no notice apparently taken by our engineering staff.
Entry.142: Bluff kept up but allowed to fire on living, good targets. Periscopes cut out of use. Jacko makes another advance in small party on Posts 3 & 4 & later on No. 1. Very Wet Storm.
Entry.143:
Storm threatening but no

rain up to 5 p.m. Turks machine guns traversing our parapets for ½ hour on & off, otherwise quiet. Conditions to return to normal at midnight. Big demonstration expected by us to follow with mines etc. Bread, Cheese, Jam, Rice & Meat issued.
Entry.144: Snow followed Saturday afternoon storm from about 10-30 p.m., still snowing this morning, everything covered thickly, bitterly cold, slight fall even in evening.
Entry.145:
Snowfall ceased but threatening to return, everything frozen still & too cold to thaw. Registered 22° below freezing point. Night clear & crisp and 
biting
 bighting.
Entry.146: Bright & clear but very cold, doing little pick & shovel work to get warm. Walked to Beach Sap for rain water lying in hollows covered with thick ice & dirty but lovely after long fast, got back 3-30 p.m., made up diary. Collected Mess tin full of snow to melt down for water. Lone Pine bombarded terribly by Turks gun fire reported 150 Casualties on Tuesday. Today’s rations bacon & tea for breakfast. Bully & Bisc. for dinner. Tea same as dinner.
Entry.147: Day off duty, collected wood & rain water for trench use. Cooking & eating most of afternoon. Evening very keen, day glorious sun. Fired opp No. 2 Bomb Pit.
Entry.148: Glorious day. Tinned meat & vegetable ration issued just lovely cold. Rice & tea breakfast, Tea evening. Letter writing & improving bunk afternoon. Bomb burst within 5 ft. of 3 of us morning fortunately no injuries. No. 2 Northern.
Entry.149: Lovely day, mild night, rations still very low, ¼ water.
Entry.150: Day fine, evening not too cold. Line quiet.
Entry.152:
Weather very nice. Mail in. Parcel from Eileen. Day off duty

spent in Gully had sponge bath.
Entry.153: Paper & Parcel mail. Sheepskin vest from home. Changed relief now on 12 to 6. Mild.
Entry.154: Weather rather cloudy but mild. Remainder of 3rd run arrived also many returned sick.
Entry.155: Weather dull & mild. Day off, spent in gully. Rally 9-30.
Entry.156: Weather Fair. Sgts day off. Naval bombardment afternoon on Road Mados .
Entry.157: Weather still dull. Nothing startling till
Entry.159:
. strong ideas of evacuation were expressed & 14th orders were issued at midday.

14th Order

Orders issued midday to pack & brand valises & blankets. Weather fair.
Entry.160: Alloted to specially divided & equal strength companies; no movement yet made. Silent stunt from 2 to 6 a.m.
Entry.161: Very cold. Day quiet, nothing doing. Beautiful sunshine and much milder. Silent 1-4 a.m.
Entry.162: Day quiet & beautifully bright. Orders restricted re evacuation. Mines connected with wires to No. 2 tunnels. Tea the only cooked rations for evening meal. Big fire at Anzac from midnight. Weather Cloudy & Foggy.
Entry.163: Day very dull, heavy cloud, fire still fierce. Water bottles filled midday. Iron rations afternoon. Paraded 4 p.m. ready for Beach. Moved off at dusk.
